50 the problem confronting us there is to discuss what short-term measures
can be taken to restore some order into the financial situation.
I have not mentioned Cuba, because Mr. Garner has been there, and possibly
he himself would like to say something about his visit to Havana.
CHAIRMAN: Thank you very much. Are there any further questions?
-'RESCIANIa I have noticed an interesting point in Mr. Iliff's report. The sending of
an expert to Turkey in order to study with the Turkish Government the
possibility of encouraging private irrvestment. That is, I think, a most
important point, as ever-fone knows one of the principal tasks of the Bank
in a few years will be the promotion of private investment. One of the
main causes preventing private investment is the series of obstacles placed
by countries against foreign experts. I think it would be very important to have an exchange of views with several governments in order to see whether it is possible to reduce, i f not abolish altogether such obstacles.
Is Turkey an exceptional case or is it part of the policy of the Bank to
have an exchange of views on this subject with various foreign governments?
CHAIRMAN: I think Mr. Garner might answer that cpestion.
GARNER: Well, when I got to Turkey I found this situation: that looking at the back
history of Turkey the Turks themselves had never gone in much for industry.
When the new Turkish Republic was set up, there was very little industry
and very little knowledge of the operations of industry. The business
people were not accustomed to going into industrial enterprises. Some of  17. )
uARNER: the races which had carried on certain enterprises were excluded from (Cont'd) Turkey. The country had the situation of a: new government and very little
industry; not, I believe, on account of ideology but because of a vacuum.
The government experimented with direct governmental funding and operation
of industrf. This went on for some years and I found on the part of the
government rome realization that that had not worked very satisfactorily.
However, I was given a pretty strong assurance that the trouble was that
the Turkish public, the capitalists, would not venture their capital.
On the other hand, I found on the part of the bus inessmen a feeling that
the government was not prepared to give adequate support. It seemed to me
that there was a situation where the Bank, acting as a friend of both parties,
might study the situation and come forward with some solution that would try
to bring the parties into agreement. I expressed that opinion to the Turkish
officials and as a result they extended an invitation to the Bank to send a
representative out to see i f we could bring forward a solution. It is my
feeling that, if we are successful in Turkey, we would be glad to do the
same for other countries i f the countries would like us to do it.
ONARAU: I would like to add a few words to Mr. Garner's statement.
There are two kinds of private investment, private investment locally and
private investment outside. The Turkish Government, as Mr. Garner said
very nicely, has realized that something should be done about this private
business because, of course, you cannot go on investing public money in
industrial affairs and leave out the private capital. Both sides of this
question have been treated like this; the Government has taken authority
from the Parliament to guarantee the transfer of profits and capital of any
foreign investor at any time it thinks necessary to take the capital or
profi ts out of the co untry. Now the Government is ready to make co ntracts
or to guarantee such transfer for foreign investors. There is no discrimi-
nation of any kind between Turkish private capital investment and foreign  18.
Â· vNARAN: capital investment and the only problem was the possible difficulty of (Cont Id) transferring it. Now the C~vernment has taken a pledge that it is going
to permit foreign investors to take capital out.
In the second place, in domestic investment, as Mr. Garner said very ably,
there is a change of mind in Government also for the domestic side of this
picture. The Parliament has passed a law lately authorizing the Finance
Minister to guarantee up to 200 million Turkish pounds, I believe, or $100
million to guarantee any local investor the dollars that he borrowed. For
instance, i f a company set up in Turkey under the auspices of the Bank on
the one hand and also by protection of the Government on the other hand,
and the Bank makes a loan to this private company, the Turkish Government
will guarantee the loan from the Bank. I think, therefore, there. is a change
of mind and views on the part of the Government on both of these questions. BRESCIANI: Will they also guarantee against commercial losses? ONARAN: The Government will guarantee a commercial loss because, i f the company cannot pay back loans from the Bank on account of losses, the Government
is guaranteeing the repayment of the dollars to the Bank. That is, it
amounts to exactly the same thing. CHAIRMAN: Thank you, Mr. iliff. Mr. Garner has just returned from a very interesting trip to Cuba with
Mr. Lopez-Herrarte and I an sure the Directors would like to hear something
about his experiences. One experience I heard was that, when he first got
there, there was a parade held in Cuba which was to protest against a loan,
and when he left there was a parade in favor of the loan. I thought you
might tell what occurred between these parades.
GARNER: We went down to Cuba in response to an inntation from the President to
come down and try to clarify what the Cubans had in mind, having in mind
what the Bank position might be. In addition to Mr. Lopez-Herrarte, a
representative of the legal firm of Sullivan, Donovan & Heenehan in New York went down. Thev have been retained for legal advice regarding matters  19. )
uARNER: affecting new financing. (Cont1d) I had a talk with the President the first morning in which he told us that
he felt that a substantial program of public works was essential to Cuba;
things such as roads, port development and other projects were important.
He also said that, Cuba having been one of the fortunate countries that
always benefits from a war instead of suffering from it, they had a very
high degree of prosperity and he was looking forward to the time when,
instead of selling 4~ to 5 million tons of sugar, they would have to sell
less sugar at lower prices and, therefore, he felt the need of injecting
some additional credit into the picture.
I did not tell him anything new because of previous conversations he had
had with )o.ir. McCloy and Mr. Black as well as the fact that Mr. Lopez-Herrarte
had outlined the policies of the Bank to the Cubans last summer. I was
really emphasizing and reiterating two or three points. The first point
comes out in connection with the fact that most of these projects require
very little import of equipment. Most of them are local currency expenditure.
I explained in great detail the position of the Bank with regard to loaning
dollars for local currency expenditure. I think we made it abundantly clear
to them although they were confused as Cuba is in a strange situation because
for a long period the dollar was their currency. I pointed out to them two
things: that if the dollar was local currency we could not loan them dollars.
They asked the question, could you make a loan to the United states Govern-
ment? I said not in dollars, but in francs or pesos. We could not lend
the United States Government dollars and we could not lend the Cuban Govern-
ment dollars for peso expenditure. The second thing: under the new Central
Bank law one year after the bank begins operations the dollar will no longer
be legal currency and the country will go on a peso economy. I told them
that, under our Articles and practice, we could not lend dollars for local
expenditures that we did not have any pesos unless the Cuban C~vernment  20.
~ARNER: wanted to make them available out of their 18%. The only possible way (Cont'd) . the Bank would be able to get pesos would be to sell peso securities in
the Cuban market. That was a possibility that might represent an exceptional
circumstance that would fit our Articles. The other point I emphasized was
that we did not finance a large variety, over-all amount of public works
loans, that we would look at a specific project and make a start if we
were satisfied and then go on in moderate &~ounts as good projects were
brought up. The third point, which bears on what Mr. Beyen said, before
we could look at a project and assess the merit of any particular project
we would have to consider the Cuban economic and firuulcial situation. They
would have to satisfy us that that was satisfactory and that they needed
to borrow, not having the resources themselves available to carry on a
reasonable program of investment.
I also pointed out that there were many indications that Cuba had very
substantial resources.
Having made that clear to the PresideIL, in accordance with the understanding
reached before I went down, told him that I was meeting with the press at
one o'clock on the first day and would be giving them a statement setting
forth the policies of the Bank, which I did. In an hour's pr-ess conference, there was very lively questioning.
I am glad to say that the press reported very accurately, and the statement
of the Bank's position was very well handled. In spite of that, I found
when I got down there that a bill had been introduced into the Senate which
was to be voted on that night, authorizing the President to contract loans
up to 200 million, and there was no mention of the Bank in the legislation.
We had never seen the legislation and it had never been discussed with us.
It was as a result of this legislation that a parade was organized against
the loans. The papers were full of it, and I said that maybe I ought to
join the parade'  21.
-ARNER: The Upper House passed the bill with one vote more than the necessary two- (Cont 'd) thirds majority. It is interesting to note that three of the opposition
senators called on us to say they were opposed to any general loan without
restrictions but they would not be opposed to any loans the Bank might make
because they knew the Bank would not make it without investigations and
necessary follow up. If an appropriate loan was proposed from the Bank,
they said they would support it. There were some most violent charges
and recriminations in the press and the radio. I have ever heard, but in
spite of that, there was not a single criticism of the Bank, and a great
marw people said i f the Bank COIOOS in, we know it will do a good job. The
debate is going on, and as Mr. Black said, a parade is being organized this
afternoon chiefly on the part of labor to support the loan which is going
to the lower house in Congress. When some members of the Government asked
me not to pay too much attention to the controversy, I said I was not
impressed by demonstrations and i f we made the loan, we would make it for a specific project.
CHAIRMAN: I think you might tell the Board the amendments to be put in the law.
GAR1IER: Apparently this legislation was desiened more trui.t with the idea of Cuba
being able to negotiate a loan with some private firms, than it applied
to transactions with the Bank. However, this particular law has introduced
or changed the amount of their public borrowing that had previously been
discussed with the B<3.t"1k. They tell us that the loan will be spent in the
various provinces of Cuba according to population or according to national
interest, so it is easy to see that such authorization would raise serious
questions as to how anyone could determine as to whether the loan was used
for the best interests of the country.
National interest might need an increase or a decrease of births, but this
situation is affected by the climate regarding it. We spent the balance
of that week talking to various Government officials, private bankers, both foreign and Cuban, business men, Cuban and American, and received a  22.
uARNER: variety of views as regards the situation of Cuba and the conditions (Cont fd) prevailing there. Our friend Luis Machado who had not been brought into the conversations before our arrival, was not brought in at all, the
President saying he wanted to carry on these conversations himself. However,
Luis met us at the airport (Mr. Lopez-Herrarte havine arrived early in the
day) and was not only very helpful to us, but a most delightful host. He
enabled us to have some very pleasant golf and go down to the beach for the
week-end, m. ich relieved the pressure of the hectic discussions that were going on. The day before yesterday, I had a final discussion with the
President, in which I again reviewed the position of the Bank so that there
is no possibility of misunderstanding the things we could not do and the
things we could do, and as the reslut of that conversation, which lasted
three hours, he asked me if we would send down a mission to study and
recommend an economic program for Cuba, including a full study of the
firiancial position of the Government, financial and tax policies. He said
cuba had no application before the Bank, and did not intend to make an
application for a loan until the studies were completed. Based on those recommendations, if an agreement could be reached that a loan is in order,
then Cuba would ask the Bank to consider Ylhat kind of loan it might be in a position to make to Cuba. I told him we would be prepared to send such
a miSsion. It would take some little time, possibly a number of months,
as in the case of the Colombian mission, but we would proceed as pronply as
pOSSible, and we would be prepared to make the same arrangements as with
Colombia and Turkey, and share the costs. He expressed appreciation of
the attitude of the Bank, and felt that maybe we could do some things
aside from a mission that would be a help to Cuba. I told him that was
our job, and we were prepared to do all we could, and he said he thoroughly
understood there was no commitment, either moral-or otherwise, on the part
of the Bank, as to whether we would make any loan or not. I pointed out  23.
~ARNER: we might come to the conclusion that Cuba had ample resources, both of (Cont 'd) dollars and pesos, to carry on a reasonable development program without a loan. If we felt that, we would tell him so. If, on the other hand,
we felt Cuba needed a loan, we would be prepared to consider it. It was
a very interesting and fascinating trip. The situation in Cuba is pretty
good. They had surprisingly good results from sugar this year. They
expected a bad result, but sales only dropped ~ million. The revenues
from sugar are pretty good and should continue for at least the next two
years as the market for sugar will be active at fairly good prices. One
of the aspects we would consider was whether now was the time for Cuba to
go on an expanded program of investment or wait until deflation had gone
further. One other point of interest. The provisions of law provide that
banks, both Cuban and foreign, can invest certain of their reserves in
Cuban securities, or in certain public foreign securities. We have raised
the question as to whether tt.e Bank bonds are eligible for that purpose.
Although the Central Bank is not yet actually operating, the Board is
constituted and has met and decided that our bonds are eligible. While
they would not take the initiative and issue a ruling to that effect, if
any bank request a ruling, they would make it and put that ruling to all
the banks. That is a fairly important measure. We have told some of the
banks accordingly and I am sure in a short time applications will be made.
Quite a sizeable amount of dollar reserves would be available for investment,
and I think it would be very helpful from the standpoint of the Bank to
have this new market open up.

talk about the loan which, in the first instance, was in the neighborhood of thirtv to forty million dollars. I think. however, that investment  24.
GARNER: bankers do not make commitments they will buy bonds until the plans have (Cont 1 d) been worked up to a final basis. The First Boston has not sent any people
down to make an investigation, and I think the thing is simply one of those
. possibilities.
BARREDA: A group of Cuban bankers were supposed to be prepared to take up a bond
issue; that was brought out in the newspapers.
GARNER: The story on that was that the Cuban banks had a great deal of pressure put
on them some weeks ago, to make some sort of offer to the Cuban Government
and they indicated that they believed that they were in a position to take
up an issue of thirty-five million pesos bonds of the Government. However,
I did not find any who felt they were in a position to take a substantial amount of bonds and hold for investment, or that they would be able to sell
a substantial amount to Cuban capitalists. That being so, I think it is the
case of an offer with a very big "if" in it. CHAIRMAN: (To )fi.r. Garner) Thank you very much.
A letter has been received from the Ambassador of Ceylon making application
for membership in the Bank. They made a similar application for memberShip
in the Fund. We plan to turn this application over to the Bank's Connnittee
on Membership for study and report. The members of that Committee are
Messrs. Chang, Hoppenot, McFarlane and Toro. As you know, the Canadian Government made available from its 18% currency
the equivalent of $8 million to be used in connection with the Brazilian
Traction, Light and Power Company loan, and also partly to be used for
disbursement under our loan to the Mexican Light and Power Company.
We have found as a matter of fact, of the $8 million we have only called
on the Canadian Government for $1.5 million which leaves $6.5 million
still undisbursed. The Brazilian '!'raction Company does not expect to
wi thdraw all of these Canadian dollars until probably December 1953, and
the same thing is true of the Mexican Light am Power Company. HOllever, t..:HAIRMAN: Canadian dollars is to be dravm down by next March. We ma:de a special (Cont'd) request of the Canadian Government to allow us to now use the undisbursed
Canadian dollars which were to be used in the Brazilian Light and Mexican
Light loans, and the Canadian Government has shown real cooperation in
allowing us to do this.
I thought it might be interesting to the Directors to show just what this
amounts to, to the Bank. If we used $6.5 million of borrowed United States
dollars in order to supply Canadian dollars on the Indian Loan, that money
would cost the Bank an average interest rate of 2.7%, so if we use Canadian
18% money, which costs the Bank nothing, we have saved the difference
between no cost and the cost on the $6.5 million borrowed dollars. Uow
w:e have to deduct from that the income which we are now getting on the
borrowed U.S. dollars by the investment of these borrowed dollars in U.S.
Government Bonds. Taking the yield of 1.25% on that money, we still save
$190 thousand. So by the Canadian Government t s allowing us to use this
money immediately, rather than deferring the use for two, three or four
years, the Bank makes $190 thousarrl.
The Bank's second training course will begin in the middle of January and
will last until the end of December next year.
We have selected seven trainees and they have all been offered appointments
and they have ,all accepted. Vie have one trainee from Ecuador, ene from
Lebanon, one from Italy, one from Norway, one from India, one from Iran
am one from the United Kingdom.
We considered 220 people for these seven places. Fifty of these people
were officially nominated by member countries and the others were people
who came to our attention through various contacts. The final selection
was made after very careful examination of all these candidates. We sent
questionnaires to their former employers, professors at their univerSities,
and other people who knew all about them. Then we had personal interviews  261
~HAIRMAN: A selection committee composed of Mr. Mendels, Chairman, Messrs. Crena de (Cont'd) Iongh, Rist Howell and Mr. Lejeune made the final choices.
In the last year's class, we had seven trainees. This class is to be
finished in December. Five of these trainees have accepted permanent
appointments on the staff of the Bank, a.nd two of them have decided to
go bac k home.
On November 15, there will be an information conference for industrialists
who are the principal suppliers for countries using the loan proceeds of
the Bank. We have invited about 25 of these industrialists and we have
received a few acceptances. We have the Treasurer of the M.W. Kellogg
Company, the Chairman of the Board of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, the
President of Internatior:ml General Electric Company, the President of

We would like to know how many Directors can attend a luncheon on November 15,
Tuesday. How many Directors can attend? (show of hands)
On November 29, there will be another information conference. This is
for an Eastern group of bankers and insurance executives, savings bank
executives. I will ask you a little bit later about lunch then, but that
will be on November 29. So i f you will make a note of that so that we can
have as many as possible for lunch then.
Just to advise the Directors, I have had some discussions and have been
giving a lot of thought to the possibility of doing some refunding of our
10-year bonds which are due in 1957. We had a talk with the Financial Policy
Committee the other day and explained to them our thinking along this line.
We have not got very far along with it and I just want to tell you that
we are thinking about it and talking about it so if you hear any remarks you
will be posted. A little later on I will come to you with a more concrete
proposal, i f I decide to go on with it.
]I there is no other business, the next meeting of the Directors will probably  lAIRMAN: be held at 10:00 o'clock, Thursday, November 17. We picked that date ,Cont'd) because there are certain items that might come up by that time. It is possible that we might change that date. If there is no other business,
the meeting stands adjourned.
One moment please. I would like to ask the members of the Pension Committee,
